name: Thakua
description: A traditional sweet from Bihar, mainly prepared as a sacred offering during Chhath Puja. Thakua is a deep-fried biscuit-like sweet made from wheat flour, jaggery, ghee, and flavored with cardamom and coconut. It is crisp on the outside and slightly soft inside, enjoyed as a festive prasad.
preCookingProcess: Grate or crush the jaggery into small pieces.
In a small pan, add water and melt the jaggery on low heat until it dissolves completely.
Strain the jaggery syrup to remove impurities and let it cool to room temperature.

Prepare the dough: In a large mixing bowl, combine wheat flour, grated coconut, fennel seeds, and cardamom powder.
Add melted ghee and mix well using your hands until it forms a crumbly texture.
Gradually pour in the cooled jaggery syrup, mixing until a firm, smooth dough forms.
Cover and rest the dough for 10-15 minutes.
Shape the thakua: Take small portions of dough and roll into balls.
Flatten each ball slightly using your palms or a rolling pin.
You can imprint traditional patterns using a fork or a mold.
Fry the thakua: Heat oil or ghee in a deep frying pan over medium flame.
Gently slide 3-4 pieces into the oil at a time.
Fry until golden brown on both sides, turning occasionally to ensure even cooking.
Remove and drain on paper towels.

postCookingProcess: Allow the thakua to cool completely before storing.
Store in an airtight container — stays fresh for up to 10 days.
Offer to the Sun God (Surya Dev) as prasad during Chhath Puja and share with family.
tipsAndTricks: Do not overheat the oil — thakua should cook slowly for even color.
You can add crushed dry fruits for extra flavor.
Use jaggery syrup at room temperature; hot syrup can make the dough sticky.
